tn.text: in-law** - Naomi is the mother of Ruth's dead husband.
Ruth became Naomi's daughter by marrying her son and further by her actions in caring for Naomi after returning to Bethlehem.

tn.ref: should I not seek a place for you?
tn.text: Naomi used this question to tell Ruth what she planned to do. AT: "I must look for a place for you!" or "I must find a husband to care for you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: a place for you to rest
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) literally in finding a house for her to live in or 2) figuratively in finding a husband to care for her. Naomi probably had both senses in mind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: female workers you have been with
tn.text: "female workers you have been working with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Naomi probably used this question to remind Ruth of something she had already told her. AT: "he is our relative." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This term indicates that the following statement is very important.
To winnow means to separate grain from the unwanted chaff by tossing both the grain and chaff into the air, allowing the wind to blow the chaff away.
This is probably a reference to rubbing sweet-smelling oil on oneself, much as women put on perfume today.

tn.ref: go down to the threshing floor
tn.text: This refers to leaving the city and heading to the threshing area. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to remove the cloak or blanket covering his feet so that they would be exposed to the cold. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"lie down at his feet"

tn.ref: Then he will tell you what to do
tn.text: The specific custom of that time is unclear, but this is usually understood as a culturally acceptable way for a woman to tell a man that she was willing to marry him. Boaz would understand the custom and accept or reject her offer.
"When he wakes up, he will"
"he was satisfied" or "he was in a good mood." It does not imply Boaz was overly drunk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"she sneaked in" or "she came in quietly so no one would hear her"
"removed his blanket from his feet"
"lay down at his feet"
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"in the middle of the night"
It is not clear what startled Boaz. Perhaps he suddenly felt the cold air on his feet.
He looked to see what startled him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: a woman was lying at his feet
tn.text: The woman was Ruth, but Boaz could not recognize her in the darkness.
Ruth spoke with humility to Boaz.

tn.ref: Spread your cloak over your female servant
tn.text: This was a cultural idiom for marriage. AT: "Marry me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
a close relative with special responsibilities toward their extended family
Boaz used this expression as a sign of respect toward Ruth as a younger woman.

tn.ref: more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning
tn.text: "even more kindness now than before"

tn.ref: more kindness in the latter end
tn.text: This refers to Ruth asking Boaz to marry her. By marrying Naomi's relative, Ruth would provide for Naomi and demonstrate great kindness to Naomi.
This refers to the way Ruth had earlier provided for her mother-in-law by staying with her and gleaning grain for food for them.

tn.ref: because you have not gone after
tn.text: "you have not pursued marriage with." Ruth could have ignored Naomi's need and looked for a husband for herself outside of Naomi's relatives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It was the duty of the closest male relative to help the widow.

tn.ref: if he will not do the duty of a kinsman
tn.text: "if he will not marry his kinsman's widow and father children for his dead relative" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"as surely as Yahweh lives." This was a common Hebrew vow.
Ruth slept at Boaz' feet. They did not have sex.

tn.ref: before anyone could recognize another person
tn.text: This time of day can be spoken of in terms of darkness. AT: "while it was still dark"
a piece of cloth worn over the shoulders
The actual amount is not stated. It was enough to be considered generous, yet small enough for Ruth to carry alone. Some think it was about 30 kilograms.
The amount of grain was so great that Ruth needed help picking it up to carry it.

tn.ref: Then he went into the city
tn.text: Most ancient copies have "he went," but some have "she went." There are English versions with both. The better choice is "he went."

tn.ref: How did you do, my daughter?
tn.text: What Ruth meant by this question can be made more clear. AT: "What happened, my daughter?" or "How did Boaz act toward you?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: all that the man had done
tn.text: "all that Boaz had done"
"Do not go empty-handed" or "Do not go with nothing" or "Be sure to take something"
This refers to the decision about who will buy Naomi's property and marry Ruth.
